column1: MathCIV;2004/05/13;;;"Freeciv never seemed mathematically accurate enough for me .. i mean it’s all well and good to just discover gravity and have newton’s workshop
column2: but to do gravity you really do need to have a basic knowledge of synthetic infinitesimal geometry
column3: and to know that you have to know geometry … but on the other hand you should have the opportunity to learn functional analysis and algebra and category theory as your civilisation progresses. You can also not just specify to build a university in your city
column4: but you can also specify what departments you want to build :)

column1: So I took freeciv and added those features to the game :)

column2: as I call it (there’s not much too it really … though it does have a brothel :) ) lurks in the computers section. it’s not terribly well documented
column3: especially re. installation
column4: but if you’ve installed any other mods it shouldn’t be very hard at all to install. If you are having trouble installing it just give me a buzz.

column1: I hope i included all the files (my freeciv directories are a bit of a mess *heh*).

column2: give it a try and tell me what you think!";;;;;;;;http://www.increpare.com/files/mathciv.zip

column1: lightcone: prototype 1;2008/10/05;lightconetitle.jpg;"and here we have the lovely lovely title screen
;I always have wanted to program some sort of game using special relativity
column2: but haven't quite figured out a good way to do it yet.  However
column3: I did think
column6: I should be able to do something with lightcones' though.  So
column7: in this simple concept game light has a finite speed
column8: which basically means that when you see things far away from you
column9: you're not seeing them as they are now
column10: but rather as they were some time in the past.

column1: I decided on simple laser weapons (which travel at the speed of light)
column2: which means that you won't ever see the ones that hit you until it's too late  :D
I made it a split-screen two-player game so that you can see for yourself how the two players can see things totally differently.  (but
column3: maybe the screens are on the wrong sides...I'll fix that in the next version  :-X )

column1: I've not actually tried playing it with anyone yet± I assume that the gameplay potential in its current form is rather minimal
column2: but I think it's still a little bit fun
column3: and I might work more on it in the future.

column2: I have two separate versions (both with sources: the mac ones should compile on linux machines as well...).

column1: Player 2: W S A D and F

there is some additional discussion of this over at the original tigsource thread.";;;http://ded.increpare.com/~locus/lightconewin.zip;http://ded.increpare.com/~locus/lightconemac.zip;http://ded.increpare.com/~locus/lightconewin.zip;C++;;
;lightconehs.gif;hopefully this won't be my last toying about with Graphics.Rendering.OpenGL;I decided to try doing a one-player prototype of this game
column2: and to do it in haskell this time as an exercise instead of C++. It’s a much more bare-bones things
column3: but might be of interest to some people (requires OpenGL and GLUT to be installed).

column2: you are a red or blue block
column3: the enemies are red blocks
column4: moving in various patterns. When you overlap with an enemy block

column1: I’m not bothering with a binary distribution
column2: but I’ve thrown up the source.";;;;;http://ded.increpare.com/~locus/lightconehs.zip;Haskell;;

Defez;2008/12/15;;;"Fascinated by the efforts of Terry
column2: in his game <a href=""http://distractionware.com/blog/?p=254"">
a retro demake of crush
column3: as well as fez
column4: I started off on a small series of studies on 1/2-dimensional variations of the mechanic common to those games.  I have four done so far± I tend to put one out whenever I'm having a particularly idle evening.   The control system in them is a bit deficient
column5: and the graphics are very basic: the point was to explore the mechanic rather than produce something polished.

column2: blocks prohibit movement when squished.
but with blocks that have 'insets'.  This broadens the mechanic somewhat
column3: but was still ultimately limited (though less limited than the first...).  Made a level editor for this one as well
column4: which helped with design a lot.

column2: more open but local: squishes down things either side of one of horizontal/vertical you are on.

column1: An observer-dependent one: squishes from either the top/bottom/left/right of the screen.  More limited in many ways
column2: but would be simpler for people to grasp I think (could be implemented as a rotation
column3: like in crush).

column1: I have a list of about five other mechanics that're awaiting implementation
column2: but I seem to have lost some interest in pursuing this much further for the moment.";;http://ded.increpare.com/~locus/defez4mac.zip;http://ded.increpare.com/~locus/defez4win.zip;;http://ded.increpare.com/~locus/defez4src.zip;C++;;
but I doubt that I will loose any sleep over putting it out in the wild either.;A short game made to take my mind off debugging troubles with a slightly larger game.  Sort of 'concept'
